title: Senior Bio Statistician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD)
Interview Descriptions:
I received an offer from Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. It didn't take me long to think about it and reject it. At best, it can be described as disrespectful. 

I conducted the interview at their location in Baltimore, MD. I was supposed to give a presentation but they weren't prepared at all. Four important people didn't show up for the interview. They are extremely disorganized. Everything seems hectic. The people who interviewed me warned from politics inside center and this turns out to be true. 

Few weeks later they offered me the job. The number was pretty insulting (less than 74 and more than 65) for someone who has a PhD with many years of experience. Their reasoning was first they don't have the money. Just imagine that JHU does not have enough resources for a reasonable salary. Second, they said the job description requires Master's and thus I should have only applied for PhD positions. They just wanted to take my PhD out of the equation although every one of their scientists team I spoke with stressed out the importance of my Education. When I mentioned that they said well we don't have the money. 

I simply rejected the offer. I don't want to work at place that depends on exploiting others. Things are clear for me. If I am over qualified for the position then you should say so from the beginning and reject my candidacy. But saying that I have the necessary qualification to succeed in this job but we will not consider your education means exploitation.    

Also, I felt I owe this to Statistics community in JHU. If I accept that poor offer, I would have made it harder to Master's holders to negotiate their salary. 

Another tactic you should be aware of, they will always encourage you to accept the job that does have a weak salary and does not respect your education by saying that we will promote you someday to a very exciting position after you get some experience. Be aware of this trap and these empty promises. It is going to take them years before even considering any type of promotion. 

I know it is easy to go blind and get too excited when you see a potential to work for a big school. Just be careful and realistic.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD)
Interview Descriptions: I saw the job ads online and applied. After applying for the position online, HR contacted me first to review my documents. After one month, a phone interview was scheduled and it took 30 mins
Interview Questions: What can you bring to Johns Hopkins University

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in May 2017
Interview Descriptions: What you should expect. PI asked how familiar I was with his work, what skills and responsibilities I had developed in my previous work experience, and had me explain these at some length to gauge how much I really knew.  PI was very flexible for the interview process and allowed an interview over the phone.
Interview Questions: What are some skills you have, but want to improve?

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Columbia, MD) in May 2017
Interview Descriptions: Contacted by phone from the executive director, who indicated did a screen and then indicated she wanted me to meet the team. When I went to the panel interview, which consisted of 5 people, I learned that the job I applied for no longer had funding. However, the director indicated some other positions that were available. 3 weeks went by, and no word. I finally reached the exec director, who indicated that they had lost a significant amount of funding and no positions were now available. I suspect that this was not a total surprise, and would like to have any applicants to this organization  be aware of this practice so they don't waste their time.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself

title: Personal Trainer Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD)
Interview Descriptions: Nothing to report in this case. The interview process varies from person to person. I took the personal training course,  the exam,  shadowed other trainers, had a mock training, and interviewed.
Interview Questions: Nothing to report in this box either.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: Very awkward, the interviewer was late to the interview and just read off questions, didn't engage at all. It felt like she didn't care about the interview or the passion I had for previous work endeavors. I felt like I just wasted my time going to this interview.
Interview Questions: What animal would you be and why?

title: Consultant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Washington, DC) in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: Thorough interview process. Very daunting. I was challenged. But I sailed through. Met one to one with management team. Each had a list of questions. Also did scenarios questions. I had prepared for that so I was able to answer with confidence.
Interview Questions: Describe yourself. Why should we hire you?

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions:
-I got an email requesting to meet in person with the professor for the interview.
-We arranged a day to meet in person, and the professor gave me a tour of the lab and even introduced me to some of the lab members
-The professor told me about the current research in the lab and the funding, also what they were looking for
-They were also impressed that I wanted to pursue my PhD later , and they said that this job would help me in getting a good experience in research
-Then I had to meet again on another day with the PI of the lab, she asked me basic questions about my past experiences
Interview Questions: -My past research experiences and topics

title: Community and Government Affairs Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions: I met with the leadership of the department and discussed my background, experience and goals with them.  They explained that the position I was interested in had been filled but they were very open and encouraging about the possibility of another position.
Interview Questions: They wanted to know if I would be willing to accept another position aside from the one I had applied for.

title: Residential Advisor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions: It was over the phone because I had worked with JHU CTY a year prior in a different location. The interview was not that lengthy.  overall, it was a good experience
Interview Questions: Describe a time when you disagreed with your boss

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: Applied online; knew it from the school's weekly email. The process takes about 3 months. Applied around December, got noticed for phone interview around the Begining of February. The interview is an hour long via phone. The interviewer is really nice.
Interview Questions: What would you do if you see two students start fighting in class?

title: Social Worker Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: I applied using the Johns Hopkins website.  Then they sent me an email to set up a phone interview.  I then had a short telephone interview with a Human resources hiring specialist.
Interview Questions: Social Work background questions.

title: Budget Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: I am right now in the middle of applying/interviewing for dozens of companies and so am pretty used to the standard phone screening process. I was pleasantly surprised to be called in for a one-on-one interview with the guy who will/would be my direct supervisor. (As opposed to having a screening call, first.) After emails back and forth regarding day/time, directions, details, etc., we were on a first-name basis and exchange felt comfortable. Gave me a positive impression of how communication would be, were I to become part of the team (Disclosure: I have worked for Johns Hopkins University in the past - completely different part of the organization, different location, etc - and so I don't know if this fact maybe fast-tracked me to a one-on-one interview)
Interview Questions: Go over your roles, responsibilities, duties, etc at your previous positions/companies

title: Math Tutor Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Bozeman, MT) in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: Simply phone call.  Asked a few questions about my teaching experience, thoughts on teaching and my education.  It was incredibly easy and I was told I was considered a top candidate for employment.
Interview Questions: What was my degree?

title: Senior Systems Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Dec 2016
Interview Descriptions: Half-day interview process, met with the team at the Baltimore MD homewood campus. Met with multiple groups of people, taken on a tour of the facilities then taken to the actual job location. I was impressed with the casual yet professional nature of the people i met.
Interview Questions: Relevant questions to the job i was applying for. Past work experiences, why i think i'd be a good fit etc.

title: Center for Talented Youth Resident Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Cleveland, OH) in Dec 2016
Interview Descriptions: There were two sections: First was about my past experiences with leadership, experience in the position, etc., meanwhile the second section involved how I would respond under certain situations relevant to the position.
Interview Questions: Name one time that you overcame severe obstacles, and how did you grow as a result?

title: Ra Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Nov 2016
Interview Descriptions: There were job offers that circulate on listservs. People always need research assistants. They met with me to get a sense of my work ethic and interests. I did not have much experience but proved I could learn it on the job.
Interview Questions: Do you have any experience working with qualitative data analysis?

title: Senior Medical Office Coordinator Interview
Application Type: The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Nov 2016
Interview Descriptions: The process was pretty standard. Telephone interview then in person interview. It was a position working for surgeons and it was probably one of the worst interview I went on in awhile. Both surgeons weren't friendly at all. The expectations for the position and what they are paying plus having to work with unpleasant people was not worth it.
Interview Questions:
The doctor had me write how I would type a letter up and I had to get on the computer and 
Make graphs for him as well

title: Student Worker Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Oct 2016
Interview Descriptions: Standard fitting in questions. Pretty quick, painless, and fitting to expectations. The interviewer was extremely kind, patient, and gracious towards me. There is very little to no pressure during the interviewing session.
Interview Questions:
How would you react to certain situations
previous work experiences

title: Infection Control Epidemiologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: I received an email after 1 week of applying to the position, i had a skype interview with the director. It was pleasant and she was very polite. Due to my inability to stay in the position for more than 2 years it was deemed to be a poor fit on their end.
Interview Questions: What is your 5 year plan?

title: Administrative Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Sept 2016
Interview Descriptions: It was a long process, but it was worthwhile because I had the opportunity to meet everyone on the team and understand the workings of the office and the culture.
Interview Questions: How I would be a good fit for this team?

title: Graduate Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Sept 2016
Interview Descriptions:
phone interview, followed by in person interview by director of department, hr, and some staff. required to cover travel expenses on your own

The process was terrible.  the managers of the department and hr never spoke and were never on the same page.  it felt like completely different conversations each time.  
the posted salary range was not actually at all what they would offer. their offer was based solely on other recent hires, not your background, or potential job.  hr was not flexible at all, rude, and condescending.  the majors within the department were very good and would have been great to work for. sadly hr completely messed up the experience
Interview Questions: basic: tell me about yourself, experience in admissions, where do you see yourself in 5-10 yrs

title: Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Sept 2016
Interview Descriptions: The first round was a phone interview. The second round was in person and involved meeting with multiple members of the team. Some parts of the in person interview were in a panel format and some were 1:1.
Interview Questions: What skills do you have that qualify you for this position?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Sept 2016
Interview Descriptions:
- online application and in person interview soon after
- got back in within a week of online application
- took some time to process details of student employment
- some difficulty in termination of job
Interview Questions: What are your skills?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: I went through an initial interview where they asked basic questions pertaining to my fit for the position, which went well. However, when they decided to move me forward they were not clear with expectations for second interview round with the PI, in which case the questions were redundant, being nearly the same as those asked in the initial interview. The interviewer seemed rather disinterested and not eager to ask questions from the start.
Interview Questions: Do you have any experience in data collection?

title: Student Monitor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Aug 2016
Interview Descriptions: Started with an email requiring me to write back with answers to the questions posed. based on my answers, I was offered the position. I then had to physically meet the employer before signing the employment contract.
Interview Questions: How I would handle hypothetical scenarios on the job.

title: Programmer Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Aug 2016
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was swift! I was contacted within two weeks of applying for the position for a phone interview. The phone interview was in a group setting and was more of a conversation than your typical hiring manager interview questions. The explained the position and what was expected from me. I told them about myself and what I was looking to offer and gain from the position. It was followed up with an in-person interview that was more of the same plus a code review.
Interview Questions: What type of projects have you worked on in the your programming skill set?

title: Programmer Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in May 2016
Interview Descriptions: Three total interviews: one phone and two in person. Relatively straightforward and not too technical. The interview process did take a long time as it took over 5 weeks total, to include each interview and additional screenings.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you had to meet two deadlines that you could notry meet.

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions:
Submit app, phone interview, acceptance/decline email

Review the course you want to sign up beforehand in depth 
Go over basic questions for general interview
Apply early and have creative answers
It is a phone interview-so make sure your phone is charged
Interview Questions:
Why do you want to work at CTY? 
What activity would you have for this class?

title: Administrative Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions: Phone call interview. We went over everything that was in my resume. Then we went on to discuss my future plans with my life. Then we went through my resume again. She told she was at the very beginning and that if I was chosen she would return my call for an interview. The line of questioning made the phone interview slightly difficult considering that I had to explain a resume in its entirety as if I did not provide one, and she missed and mixed up most of my experiences. Most of the call was spent trying to clarify my resume and the flow and my actual experience despite it being in a one page resume.
Interview Questions: Why did I come to Baltimore?

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions: Hiring process can take several days. Interview depends on the individual laboratories. Questions asked are quite laid back and there is usually just a phone screen followed by a 1:1 interview. They definitely look into recommendations you provide, so that should be strong.
Interview Questions: What did I do in my previous research?

title: Senior Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Mar 2016
Interview Descriptions: Applied in writing with CV and cover letter. Made a follow-up telephone call. After about 3 weeks, was asked for a telephone interview. This was not particularly friendly. One person was very aggressive. Kept alleging that I had made mistakes in my past career. But that made me comfortable to be just as aggressive in my replies.
Interview Questions: Why did you quit your last job?

title: Accountin Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Mar 2016
Interview Descriptions: Everything was very friendly and handled in a very positive manner. Applied on the web site. Received a call to set up a screening call with the hiring manager. Waited about a week and received a call for a panel interview.
Interview Questions: What was the most difficult job you were faced with and how did you respond to it?

title: Residential Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Mar 2016
Interview Descriptions:
Interview was conducted by Skype in early spring. The interviewer asked basic questions about performing the basic functions of the job and appeared to be hoping I would give verbal confirmation rather than evaluating my qualifications as a candidate. 

My interviewer did NOT communicate I would only get two days off every three weeks (actually *more* than many of my coworkers!). I found this out only after I had accepted the job and she sent my my contract to sign. This was a problem for me, as I was in a site close to my hometown, and was expecting to be able spent time with my family during the summer, since I've been living across the country from them for the last two years. (In fact, I communicated this to the woman during the interview!) In the end, I only saw them twice in seven weeks.

The interviewer likewise implied this would be an easy office job. Opening week was 12-14 hour days for seven days straight. Keep in mind I had just met all my coworkers, and dealing with that level of stress among coworkers made it far worse. We had two more crunch periods like this at Intersession and Closing. I felt like the interviewer had deliberately mislead me about the nature of the job.
Interview Questions: Are you comfortable transporting students in a van?

title: Administrative Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: Applied online and heard from HR a couple of weeks later offering to set up a 1:1 phone interview. Did the phone interview, very typical questions. Told I would hear back within a week - week and a half, which I did. I was offered a chance to come in for a interview. It was from 12:00-3:30 and took place on two different campuses. The Eastern campus had me sit with HR and go over typical questions.. explain a time when this happened and then had me do a Excel, Word and proof reading test. These were not what I was expecting because you can only perform the task the way the test wants you to, so forget and short-cuts you know. After that I had 30 min to get to the other campus but of course construction blocked the road, this was very frustrating. One guy was sick so I met with 3 people in total, 2 other administrative coordinators who were very nice and the higher up I would be working for. They were all very nice but within a week I received an email that they would be perusing someone else.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you did not get along with a co-worker.

title: Research Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: There was only one round of interview and it went quite well. My potential boss and a peer data analyst interviewed me. Mostly general questions. They were interested in how comfortable I am with analytic software and I elaborated a lot on my relevant experience. The rest of the interview I felt that they were asking many questions to find out what type of person I am. They want to see if I can fit with the rest of the groups. Fun question at the end: if you want to be an animal, what would you be?
Interview Questions:
Are you familiar with Stata/SAS and some mobile phone data collection tool?
What is your level of comfort in using Stata?
What is your preferred managerial style?
How do you describe your personal style.

title: Program Assistant With CTY Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: Smooth. Had a fairly long list of standard questions, some were more unconventional than others. Interviewer was nice, and the atmosphere was relaxed. Director e-mailed a month and a half after I submitted my application and we found a time to Skype. Turnaround time was quick, a couple days.
Interview Questions: What would you do if a student said to another student, "that's so gay"?

title: Administrative Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 days. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: Interview was quick and just a phone interview then I was offered the job on the spot. I went through a staffing agency who I interviewed with a few days before hand. Staffing agency told me they had a position with the University, someone from the University called, interviewed me via phone, offered me the position, then sent me for a drug test.
Interview Questions: What are your strengths?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: I sent out cold email to ask about the funding opening. Got a skype interview request and talked over skype for about 1hr, during which I gave a presentation about my about to finish PhD work. They know my supervisor in person but as far as I know they didn't check reference.
Interview Questions: When will you be available?

title: Maintenance Technician HVAC Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: The process is very long. It includes 2 interviews: one with the immediate supervisor and manager and one with HR Rep. It was very frustrating due to poor communication. I keep giving them information they needed for references and they continued to call a lot trying to get my work references straight. Off never had any place have as much difficulty just checking a reference. But I assumed it was just an indication of their thoroughness. I was wrong.
Interview Questions: Some of our areas are very dirty. Do you mind getting dirty?

title: Maintenance Technician HVAC Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: I was called about an opening and was asked to interview. I went through a 2 part interview with the direct supervisor and manager. Then I had to wait for background checks and reference checks. This took about 2 mos. or more to get an offer.
Interview Questions: Tell use a little about your background.

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD)
Interview Descriptions: After applying online, it took a few weeks for HR to forward on all of the applications/resumes to the hiring department.  Once that occurred, I had an initial phone screen with one of the hiring managers.  I was then asked to come into Baltimore for an in-personal panel interview (3 individuals).  They narrowed down the candidates and had the last few come in again to meet with yet another investigator for a 1:1 interview.
Interview Questions: General questions about education and prior research experience.  Some behavioral questions about ones strengths and weaknesses, how you would handle a difficult situation, etc.

title: Library Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD)
Interview Descriptions: Several weeks after applying to another, similar position, I was contacted by HR to set up an in-person interview on campus. The interview consisted of a panel meeting with what I believe was the hiring committee, followed by a discussion with potential coworkers. I had been told that there would be a tour of the department, but was not offered one during the interview. The whole process took about 1 1/2 hours.
Interview Questions: How do you manage stress?

title: Graduate Student Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: I originally was looking into a position with one faculty member. She didn't have anything open, but introduced me to a couple of other faculty members who were looking for research help.
Interview Questions: What areas of research are you interested in?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, NY) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: I contacted my boss by email and then if he asked me to give a presentation as he thought my background was match. I then gave a talk in the group. then was the Q&A and talked individually with the group members.
Interview Questions: almost academic questions and career plan

title: Doctoral Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: The interview was conducted on skype. The professor contacted me through email to setup the interview.  Focused on my projects and resume, with some basic questions about my interests in the opportunity.
Interview Questions: Asked me about passive scalar mixing in turbulence.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: I sat down with the museum staff. It was fairly quick and felt more like a conversation than an interview. They asked me about my previous experience and why I was interested in the Homewood Museum.
Interview Questions: What is your previous museum experience?

title: Senior Research Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: Was recommended by a friend. Touched base with the Field Director and got an immediate response to schedule a phone interview. Spoke on the phone and formally introduced myself and was scheduled to participate in an in person interview.
Interview Questions: What have you heard about this position and what makes you qualified.

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: I applied online, received an email to schedule a phone screen. The phone screen was straight forward, receiving information about the position, and describing myself and skill set. The in-person was relaxed but still professional, like a college setting. I met with the HR recruiter, manager, and other lab technicians, and toured the facilities. Within a four days I received a call back.
Interview Questions:
Describe your greatest weakness? 
What was your favorite and not so favorite course in college? 
Where do you see yourself 3-5 years from now?

title: Administrative Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions:
My first interview was over the phone with the manager of the department. She asked basic interview questions, was fairly harmless. I stumbled a few times, but they don't seem to care much so long as you seem really interested in the position. 

Second interview was intense! Was 10 minutes late due to being lost. I had to come in for three group interviews for the day, which lasted 3 hours. Met all of the important department staff. Once I completed that, they told me to expect an answer within two weeks. 

Roughly 10 days later (including the weekend), I was contacted via email by HR to come in for one final interview. The following say after the HR interview, I was offered a salary.
Interview Questions: where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: PhD Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: You specify which PIs you're interested in talking to and they setup 3 of them to interview with.  You get about half an hour talking to each one.  It's basically to just make sure you're actually interested and you match the application you put forth.  If you made it this far, you should be good to get in.
Interview Questions: What kind of research are you interested in?

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Nov 2015
Interview Descriptions: I sent in my resume through the JHU job posting webpage. I was applying to one of the labs on campus. After a few days the PI emailed me asking to schedule an interview. About 2 weeks after my initial application I was working in the lab. At the time the lab needed to hire quickly, which probably helped with how quickly I got the job.
Interview Questions: Do you have any experience with PCRs or handling mice?

title: Research Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Nov 2015
Interview Descriptions: Applied online, next HR reached out to me. I met the department managers and had an in person interview about what I knew about the role and if I had any experience. I did an internship to related to similar work and talked about that project. I was offered the position. I had to take a drug test and pass a health screening.
Interview Questions: Discuss difficult situations that you dealt with, and what was your process.

title: Research Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Nov 2015
Interview Descriptions: I was called by the research project administrator rather than HR. They described the project and job briefly to me to see if I was interested. They then sent me several survey questionnaires in pdf that had been filled out (bogus versions - all the same survey) and asked me to analyze it, no other instructions. I then had a group interview where half was spent asking normal interview questions and the other half was spent going through the survey write-up where I explained my approach, thinking, and results. Note that the job was not for data analysis per-se, they just wanted to get an idea of what I could do with few instructions and what type of work I produced.
Interview Questions: Describe how you would balance multiple workloads with different deadlines?

title: Clinical Laboratory Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Nov 2015
Interview Descriptions: Met with potential employer to see what kind of fit the job had.  It wasn't a good fit, so she will pass my resume on to those folks who will be more likely to use my job skill set.  Very professional and friendly.
Interview Questions: What experiences have you had at Johns Hopkins, what are your main skills?

title: Academic Program Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Nov 2015
Interview Descriptions: I was interviewed by one person first and then by two at once. After that I was interviewed by 3 additional people. It was to much no over the top for the type of position it was. Then it took another month to finally hear back. Whole process took way too long.
Interview Questions: They asked about my previous position.

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: I applied online. And my previous adviser recommended me to my current adviser. After I passed the screen of the university (they will check GPA, Tofel, GRE, etc.), I got one phone call interview since I am an international student. Then I got the offer.
Interview Questions: What you have done in the past

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Oct 2015
Interview Descriptions: I applied online via the JHU website and was contacted by a department member to interview. I was given several times to choose from and I set up the interview via Skype. I was also given the names of those who would interview me. It was an audio only panel interview with several pre-determined questions for the position with time for questions at the end. It lasted about 45 minutes in all. I was told to expect to hear a decision by the following Friday, which I did not.
Interview Questions:
Tell use why you are interested in this position and what experience makes you a good fit.
Tell us how you encourage diversity.
Tell us about a mistake you made in the past and what you learned from it.
When people first meet you, what do you think they first notice?
Tell us about a time you improved a weakness (or another variation on "tell us about a weakness").

title: Operations Student Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Oct 2015
Interview Descriptions: It was all about your personality and ability to do independent work. Be sure to talk about your organizational skills, time management, and responsibilities. they interviewers were very sweet and liked to have a conversation more than asking questions.
Interview Questions: What are your strengths and weaknesses?

title: MSE CBID Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Corvallis, OR)
Interview Descriptions: Skype interview with Johns Hopkins professor and alumni of the program. Mostly behavioral questions and a few questions about my research experiences. Overall both interviewers were very friendly and easy to communicate with. Near the end they asked some tricky questions regarding the entrepreneurial aspect of the program and its ties to developing countries, which was the most difficult part of the interview
Interview Questions: How would you apply your past research to a developing country and why?

title: Assistant Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD)
Interview Descriptions: Initial interview via phone and then came in for 2nd interview. Met with about 5 people in the group 1:1. Had lunch with the division head to discuss the job and hiring process in detail. Standard interview with focus on my interests and future aspirations. Was on site essentially from early morning to mid-afternoone. Everyone was very nice.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years? What are your strengths?

title: Lab Tech Interview
Application Type: The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: I applied for 22 jobs and was contacted to interview for 1 about a month later. Everyone was extreme nice. The interview started out with HR telling me about all of the benefits. I completed a technical worksheet. After being interviewed by the HR I was interviewed by 2 lab managers. I walked through the lab for a tour.
Interview Questions: What 5 components do you need for PCR?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: the interview process was just fine, but the hiring process took a very long time and I wasn't happy about that. The interview process was easy enough to set up, but I had to wait several weeks to be officially paid and on the payroll.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position?

title: PhD Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: One day interview process. General introductions of each field in the department was given in the morning. Candidates were taken to lunch by senior grad students to learn more about the department. Individual interview with professors of interest happened in the afternoon. The overall atmosphere was very friendly.
Interview Questions: Why did you choose this specific major?

title: Senior Research Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: It was multi-staged. First with HR department; then with the local department looking to employ a candidate. HR interview was more general and broad: tell me about yourself stuff; while local department was more specific to the advertised position and very very thorough. You need to know the meat and onions of how to do the job.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself. How do you interpret diversity?

title: Office Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions: I had one phone interview with my current supervisor. She was really nice. The interview lasted about 30 mins. The whole process took about two weeks with back and forth calls to see how they could work with me schedule.
Interview Questions: I was given several in-office scenarios to see and asked how i would handle each one.

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD)
Interview Descriptions: Brief - asked about my previous research. They assumed they knew everything about me from my CV - this was a terrible assumption. They were more interested in telling me about what they do and everything I could become involved with. If I could go back, I would ask about previous post-docs (what they did, how long they were there, frequency of publication, why they left, and what they are doing now) and I wouldn't take the job without a career development plan.
Interview Questions: I was not asked difficult questions - explain this project, how did you do that, etc.

title: Senior Administrative Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jul 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview was very informal, laid back. I spoke with each doctor that I would be supporting, answering their questions. One of the doctors didn't have any questions for me, instead he told me why the department didn't need to hire another person. Ironically, he asks me to do things for him  regularly.
Interview Questions: If i minded talking with patients.

title: Graduate Research Assistant (Part-time) Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jul 2015
Interview Descriptions: I got to know this position through job listing in my department. I sent my CV along with a short cover letter to the professor directly and received his reply in one week. He then arranged an online interview via Skype. I was notified the results two days after the interview.
Interview Questions: Most questions were related to my previous work experience, and some questions regarding my research ability were also asked.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: It was straight forward. I applied, got a response and went for an interview. they concentrated more on my research skills, we went through the research to ensure i was interested in the research topic. the entire process took 2 weeks. It required a lot of paper work.
Interview Questions: what is your career goal

title: Prospect Research Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: Both interviewers focuses a lot on working with difficult people and it was apparent there are a  lot of conflicts in the workplace, based on the questions, I decided not to pursue position.  It was clear this office had a lot of issues working with other departments.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you disagreed with a colleague.

title: Lab Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: reach at 12:00 pm, talk in a small room, first i describe myself, where i came from, what i like , why i apply this job , what i can do for the job .then he ask about what i can do, what i want to do. and say some thing about the job, what should do of the job. that's all. that's all.
Interview Questions: can i use photoshop?

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: Students are asked to provide transcript to prove academic excellence, and then you are asked to fill in a question sheet to answer several behavior questions, including your course preference,  your past teaching experience, your favoriate professor to work with etc.
Interview Questions: What do you expect to gain at this position

title: Senior Research Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: It was a one hour skype group interview. The study manager, statistician and PI interviewed me together. Most of the questions were about my previous analysis experience and they asked more details based on my answers. It was a nice and easy going interview.
Interview Questions: Tell us one previous work you were proud of

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: I went to the career fair and they looked at my resume and we had an information chat. Then I had a brief behavioral interview over the phone. The interviewer was very nice and personable. All of the questions were common sense.
Interview Questions: What would you do if a kid said an offensive comment to another student?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: My interviews were conducted over Skype, approximately 2 weeks apart.  I presented work from my doctoral thesis, answered a few scientific and personal questions, and was given the opportunity to pose questions.  The whole process was casual and unassuming.
Interview Questions: I was asked about possible project proposals

title: Vice President Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: I submitted my resume through a recruiter. I was contacted for a phone interview. They asked tell me about yourself and why do you think you are qualified for the position. Then I had an in-person interview with the senior recruiter. I was referred to a full panel interview in Baltimore. They said they would call me about next steps within a week.
Interview Questions: In less than 5 minutes tell us about your background and how it led you here today.

title: Academic Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: The process was very long and unnecessarily drawn out. I applied for the position in February, and after a few months of back and forth I was offered the job in July, with a start date of August 1.
Interview Questions: Q. How would you handle a faculty member that might be a little bit difficult?

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview consisted entirely of a ~30 minute telephone interview, during which I was asked standard interview questions, and then given several hypothetical classroom scenarios involving young students (ages 11-14) and asked to describe how I would respond to them.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you had to manage conflict with a supervisor. How did you respond to the situation? What actions did you take to resolve it without compromising the quality of your work?

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: Saw an email looking for students seeking to be teaching assistants. Then responded, and was given a choice of interview times later that week. The interview was quick, and focused on ascertaining academic expertise.
Interview Questions: What grades did you receive in the following courses.

title: Human Resources Generalist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: I was originally supposed to meet with 2 people for the interview; on the day of the interview, one of them was out sick. I met with the head of the department, but the questions asked were very vague. I enjoyed the interview though and thought it went well. I was told I would hear from someone to reschedule the meeting with the sick individual, but never heard back. A week later, I received a thanks, but no thanks email. Looking back, it sounds like they already had an individual in mind for the position, but were doing due diligence in interviewing others, who never even had a chance for the job.
Interview Questions: Tell me alittle bit about yourself.

title: University Administration Aide Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions:
There were three phases--a phone interview and then two separate in-person interviews. The first was with the hiring manager, who described the job and asked questions about resume. The second was a panel interview.

Was disappointed with the low-ball salary offered in exchange for skills/qualifications possessed. No opportunity for raises. Would have to answer e-mails in evening, which would dilute low pay further. Not to mention the costs of "benefits" which would also reduce net pay. Unfair. And, I had to decline.
Interview Questions: Tell me you resolved an issue at a previous job.

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Mechanicsburg, PA) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: It was a phone interview; pretty simple questions. I also had to submit a sample lesson plan; we talked about that for a while, and then went through a handful of "what would you do in this situation" kinds of questions. The interviewer was very friendly, he made it easy to speak naturally, as nervous as I was.
Interview Questions: How would you handle a kid who had a crush on you?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview was very smooth. Typical presentation with faculty members asking questions about your research and possible interactions with the project at Hopkins. I will definitely will recommend to study the research going on at the specific Department where you are applying and how your current research can be connected to the research that is done in the Department.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this project?

title: Health Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (New York, NY) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: They asked me preference based questions without providing a guidebook such as should I put a bandaid on a kid or have the kid do it themselves.  They never contacted me back or gave me feedback, instead they offered me a different position than the one I applied for.
Interview Questions: A kid throws up, should you call the RN/Manager?

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: Two technical phone screens with detailed, repetitive questions in areas such as ASP .NET MVC development, web development, SQL Server, etc.  In-person programming test composed of creating three SQL Server queries against the AdventureWorks sample database and an ASP .NET MVC challenge involving adding a new field to a form and storing it in SQL Server using Entity Framework.
Interview Questions: What is the difference between VARCHAR and NVARCHAR in SQL Server?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Los Angeles, CA) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: By phone. Simple questions about your résumé first. Then, some questions on your personal background. Overall, a very relaxed interview. To note, you really have to be prepared to show that you know a lot about the field of the work that you are applying for.
Interview Questions: Elaborate on your research projects.

title: Visiting Assistant Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: Great visit with faculty and stuff. Tour of the facilities. Questions about teaching style.  We talked a lot my previous teaching experience and how I prefered to use technology. They also asked about which other courses I would be interested in teaching.
Interview Questions: How to do motivate students?

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions:
It was a very informal process as it was a student position at one of the school's centers. 

I saw the position posted on our school job board so I emailed the principal investigator directly to indicate my interest. They promptly emailed me back, and suggested a time to meet to discuss the details of the position. It was hardly an interview as the "interview started" by them telling me more in depth information about the project, then they asked me if I would still be interested, then they told me the pay, and that was that.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this topic?

title: Course Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: They told me to come to a room to interview. They asked me some trivial questions like why you want to work for us, and what you would do if a student ask for help. They care more about what you have taken for courses, especially the one you are about to become a course assistant for, than how you do in your interview. Basically, if you get an interview and don't do stupid things, then you are in. Others might beg to differ, but that was my impression.
Interview Questions: What you would do if a student ask for help?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: General questions about education background, research and intern experience, course project, etc. most of them are behavioral questions. Then they introduced their institution current projects, and work style. They also asked me to submit writing samples and data work after the interview.
Interview Questions: Tell us about your experience working with data

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online, completed an interview via Skype by two members of the department, and then was interviewed in person by three members of the department. In-person interview lasted about one hour. Date of application to date of offer was very long - over 2 months. 

This job was posted without a salary range, unusual for Hopkins.
Interview Questions: Don't recall. None of the questions were particularly challenging.

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Nov 2014
Interview Descriptions:
After I applied for the Research Technologist position with JHU, I was contacted a week or two later by the Director of the laboratory by email in which a phone interview was setup.The actual phone interview didn't feel like an interview at all. The Director gave more detail about what the position was and what it entailed and asked if I was still interested. When I said I was, a formal interview was scheduled. The formal interview was fairly easygoing as it was an an entry-level position I had applied for, and the Director was very kind. Emphasis was on experience with questions like: it says here on your resume that you were involved in this project. Can you tell me more about your role and what you did? In addition, they were also interested in the coursework that I had taken that was relevant to the job. I met with several members of the laboratory and got to ask questions in which they were helpful. The interview was also more listening than talking. They want to inform you of their research goals to see if it's worth pursuing for you. I'd suggest becoming familiar with their research by reading journal articles so you can not only keep up with them, but you can ask relevant and "smart" questions.

Therefore, if you know your resume inside out, you will ace this interview. The position was offered to me by email the same day as the interview. However, I still sent thank you notes by email or LinkedIn with everyone I interviewed with.

The hiring process was far less easy. Many, many, many forms are required for hire, and I cannot tell you how many times I filled out the same form more than twice. Be prepared to do background checks and drug tests and the like. The entire process took a little over a month.
Interview Questions: On this interview, there were no tricky questions because it was an entry level position, and they were desperate.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Nov 2014
Interview Descriptions: I was referred by my professor because of my outstanding academic background. The interview is relatively easy because my professor already knows what I'm capable of doing. It's basically just reviewing my resume and career path with the details of the projects I'm going to research.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions:
Applied through HR. Emailed directly by the PI and asked if I would be available for a phone call. Contacted by PI for phone interview where I was asked about my previous research as an undergraduate student, specifically in regards to the research I might be doing in the lab. At the end of the call, I was invited for in-person interview the next week. 

Drove up to Hopkins and interviewed with PI of the lab, then met with lab manager and senior techs, finally closed interview with PI. The entire interview took roughly 2-3 hrs and everyone was very pleasant.
Interview Questions: Most difficult questions were the probings about my future research as an undergrad, and even those were not too technical or difficult. Most of the interview was just getting to know me and making sure my very recent B.S. in Biology gave me enough knowledge to start working in a lab at an entry level position.

title: Senior Research Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions: the hiring process includes 2 steps, first, you need to interview with HR, this step includes behavioral questions, about an hour long.  then you will meet with your future employer, regarding the specialty knowledge, about one hour as well. Some people got another chance to meet with the employer again or the future team member as well.
Interview Questions: Give an example of a situation that you solved a difficult problem.

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: Multiple interviews were required beginning with an informal phone interview. After that I had a preliminary in person interview, and then moved on to a final interview where I met with multiple team members and  got a real feel for the company.Overall it allowed me to get a good sense of how the office was run and to let me get a good idea of who I would be working with.
Interview Questions: What makes you interested in working for Johns Hopkins University?

title: Senior Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: Very easy interview itself - proved my work through interning for months beforehand. Easier if have a personal connection to make introductions. Because interned, didn't have a formal interview. I've heard some can be hard and some can be with many people at once or separately.
Interview Questions: Specifics about technical skills.

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: After the application process, I emailed a couple professors to check for their plans of hiring new graduate students. The recruiting process differs from department to department, but usually professors had the call for their own graduate assistants. The professor who was interested called me to his office (I was a master student then), and asked me about my chemistry background, intention to stay in JHU and then gave me the offer the next day.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Learning Den Tutor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: You must fill out an application form online and then interview in person, the whole interview was very enjoyable.  The interview focus on teaching skill rather than subject knowledge.  The interviewer was very nice, polite and walked me through the whole process and kept in touch about my performance these last two years.
Interview Questions: what is your greatest skill as a potential tutor

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: I had two phone interviews. The first was a screener to make sure I actually was who I claimed to be and to make sure I could speak in complete sentences. Before the second, I was asked to prepare a sample lesson plan for a unit and submit it. In the second interview, I was questioned about how I would deliver the lesson, what would happen if things went wrong, and how I would approach certain common or uncommon classroom situations.
Interview Questions: A lot of questions about whether or not I would break certain seemingly harmless rules.

title: Academic Service Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions: There was a very brief interview, followed by a very extensive background screening that took quite a bit of time. There wasn't a clear organized structure for the interview. I arrived expecting to meet with one person who turned out, was not involved in the interview process.
Interview Questions: How would you rate your ability to multitask?

title: Administrative Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions: To even get an interview is a huge win since there are so many applicants for every job posting. However, once you get an interview, it can take MONTHS to even hear back from anyone about the position, even if you did get the job or not. I applied for many jobs through their website and interviewed for a handful. I received two job offers from two different departments: one department gave me a phone interview, then a face to face with two different people, and then two months later I received a job offer. The other department gave me a face to face interview with two people at the same time and then a second interview three weeks later and verbally told me I had the job, but I never received anything written from them and I accepted a position with another company. I still have not heard from them and it's been almost a year.
Interview Questions: How do you prioritize your workload?

title: Program Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: Applied through HR and spent a day shadowing in the lab. Interviewed with several members of the lab and was given the opportunity to ask the person presently holding the position many questions. It was a thorough interview that allowed me to interview the lab as much as they were interviewing me.
Interview Questions: PI did not ask me typical interview questions. Be able to speak intelligently and in detail about your research experience and specific projects/outcomes

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD)
Interview Descriptions: I was referred by my boss from my previous postdoctoral position in Johns Hopkins University. I was invited to come and talk to my potential employer, and Research Associate from the same lab and present my previous research on the lab meeting. Everything went smoothly and I got an offer a few days later.
Interview Questions: No difficult questions - mostly about my research and skills and future plans.

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: I applied the position through JHU website and got an email from HR to setup in person interview. Interview Questions: What is your greatest strength? What is your greatest weakness? Why are you leaving your job?
Interview Questions: Are you overqualified for this job?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: I was interviewed in two rounds.  The first was a general overview of my previous experience, my hobbies, standard questions.  The second was a question/answer session about hypothetical situations in terms of data gathering, curricula formation and various other topics.  They had me edit some mock teacher guides; we went over my work together after the initial interview.
Interview Questions: What was the last book you read?

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: The interview process for a TA is very informal. My experience was as follows: for a large course, I responded to an internally circulated notice that they were looking for TAs. The course administrator reviewed my course background, and requested a short written response to answer 1-2 short questions. I knew the course administrator from my previous coursework so a more formal interview was not done. For the small courses, the professor already knew me from my previous coursework, so we only discussed the details of the positions themselves during the 'interviews' - I didn't have to answer the typical interview questions.
Interview Questions: What interests you in being a TA for this course?

title: Summer Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: Applied for a summer internship position in December of 2013 and didn't hear a word from them until mid May of 2014 when I received a rejection email. Thoroughly unimpressed with their lack of any semblance of professionalism or grip on reality (in what scenario would someone seeking employment in June wait until May to accept other job offers because of an employer who hadn't made any effort to contact an applicant for nearly half a year?!). Won't be applying again.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Customer Service Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: Very simple. They ask you basic questions about your work history and smiled the whole time. Very polite. They did not ram a bunch of pointless questions to you. Supervisors seemed very interested in you.
Interview Questions:
What do you do at your current job?
What did you like most about your job?

title: Laboratory Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: It's who you know, there was no real formal interview. It's who you know, there was no real formal interview. It's who you know, there was no real formal interview. It's who you know, there was no real formal interview.
Interview Questions: Asked if I was ok with the kind of work I'd be doing.

title: Research Program Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: I did a phone screen. I received and email a week later to do a face to face interview with the P.I., Research Program Manager, and Research Program Coordinator. I had the interview and I sent a thank you email. They told me that the would check my references. Two weeks later I was offered the job.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position?

title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: Applied by email, then phone interview and personal interview
Interview Questions: If I was sure that I want to move to Baltimore.

title: PhD Student Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: Just submit the application and got an telephone interview.
Interview Questions: nothing really difficult one, just experience

title: Trainer Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: Very relaxed interview process. By the time the interviewed my they had already interviewed 50+ people, so they saw my credentials and ran a relaxed process
Interview Questions: How would you deal with rude Doctors?

title: PhD Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD) in Apr 2014
Interview Descriptions: I was interviewed on Skype after the committee like my application. I was asked about my previous research and research interests in the program, and why I thought I was a fit. Was later asked if I had any questions about their program, which they answered satisfactorily.
Interview Questions: Describe your previous research

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University in Apr 2014
Interview Descriptions: Applied and interviewed in April or May. The interview was by phone and it was completely behavioral. A lot on how you would react given a certain situation with children. On the technical side, they just ask how well prepared you feel to teach the kids and what experiences make you feel prepared for the job.
Interview Questions: How would react to a child who was very rebellious or a child who you suspected had a crush on you?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University (Baltimore, MD)
Interview Descriptions: The interview spans two days.  There will be 5-10 other candidates interviewing with you.  You will meet one-on-one with 5-8 professors, mostly of your own choosing (arranged by the department administrator beforehand via email).  They will ask about your education, research experience, career goals and other interests.  You will have dinner at a professor's home with some of the other candidates.  Not only do they want to make sure that you are intelligent and hardworking, but also that you get along with people and carry an interesting conversation.  During lunches and a poster session there will be many opportunities to interact with the graduate students who are already in the program.  They will also be making note of whether or not you are asking good questions and if you seem like someone they would like to work with.  Be sure to ask graduate students about what they like/don't like about the school and/or the professors they work with.
Interview Questions: What are your career plans?  What kind of research are you interested in?  Why did you get a "C" in that undergrad chemistry class?

title: Reimbursement Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at The Johns Hopkins University
Interview Descriptions: It was a pretty standard interview.   The only part that through me off was how disengaged the interviewer (hiring manager) was with her body language.  Although the conversation was fairly normal and fluid, she never really looked at me.  Her body was twisted away from me, she spent the entire time fidgeting with a desktop toy.  She said they would be making a decision in two weeks.  I took six weeks for a response.  I was advised during the interview that everything takes longer than expected with it comes to HR, so it was not too much of a surprise.
Interview Questions: I was given a complex claim issue and was asked to map out the steps and resources I would use to resolve the specific issue.

title: Teaching Assistant Interview

title: Research Technologist Interview

Interview Descriptions: Initial communication by email to set up interview.  I applied to position 3 weeks before.  The interview was relaxed but manager told me she has a bunch of interviews set up.  Did not ask me any questions about my previous experience. She did say I was overqualified immediately.  I then met with the laboratory manager who told me she had been working for the company for 25 yrs and I will not take her job.
Interview Questions: Unexpected was Why do you want this job you cant have mine so why.

Pleasant group of people who asked typical interview questions. The experience was a nice balance of questions and conversation. Unfortunately, did not receive an offer. title: Research Technologist Interview
